S0021-9517(25)00394-X 10.1016/j.jcat.2025.116328 The Author(s) Fig. 1 (a) XRD patterns of Ti3AlC2, Ti3C2-ML and Ti3C2-DMSO, (b) AFM frontal view of Ti3C2-ML. The values indicate the thickness of the MXene particles on which the colored lines appear. (c) From left to right, HRTEM image of Ti3C2-DMSO (the inset corresponds to Fast Fourier transformed of the whole HRTEM image showing the (0 1 ¯ 10) facet of Ti3C2 MXene) and HAADF-STEM images of Ti3C2-DMSO at 5 and 1 nm scale length. Fig. 2 High resolution XP spectra corresponding to the experimental C 1s, Ti 2p, O 1s, F 1s, Cl 2p and N 1s core levels for Ti3C2-DMSO MXene (plotted in black) as well as their best fit to individual components whose assignment and binding energy are indicated in the plots. Fig. 3 Time-yield plot of 1,3-diisopropyl-2-(p-tolyl)guanidine in presence of a) Ti3C2-DMSO and b) Ti3C2-ML at ■ 90 °C (black), ● 100 °C (red), ▲ 110 °C (blue), ▾120 °C (pink) and 130 °C (green). Reaction conditions: 7.5 mg of the catalyst, p-toluidine (0.25 mmol), diisopropylcarbodiimide (0.35 mmol), toluene as solvent. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 4 Time-yield plots of 1,3-diisopropyl-2-(p-tolyl)guanidine formation catalyzed by a) ■ Ti3C2-DMSO (red), ● Ti3C2-HCl (green), ▲ Ti3C2-APS (blue) and ▾ Ti3C2-TBAOH (magenta) at 100 °C; b) Time-yield of 1,3-diisopropyl-2-(p-tolyl)guanidine in presence of ■ Ti3C2-ML (black) ● Ti3C2-FL (purple) and ▲ Ti3C2-FL-500 (pink) at 130 °C. Reaction conditions: 7.5 mg of the catalyst, p-toluidine (0.25 mmol), diisopropylcarbodiimide (0.35 mmol), toluene (1.5 mL). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 5 Top 35-atom model MXene cluster (MXene), from two different views. Distances of two Ti-Ti and Ti-C bonds shown explicitly. Bottom: Structure of the deprotonated toluidine attached to the MXene cluster model (MXene catalyst). Also shown the adsorption of DIC. Blue = N, Red = O, White = H, Green = F, Gray (small) = C, Gray (big) = Ti. Some atoms of MXene on the DIC adsorption structure have been omitted for the sake of clarity. The distance is indicated in Å. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 6 Cycloaddition TS (TS1), intermediate 1 and aniline adsorption (2) on the MXene cluster. Some atoms of MXene structure have been omitted for the sake of clarity. Distances are indicated in Å. Fig. 7 First part of the DFT calculated reaction pathway for the guanylation of DIC by p-toluidine First TS has an activation energy (Ea) of 121.7 kJ/mol. The adsorption of p-toluidine is exothermic with an energy of –96.6kJ/mol. Key steps are represented schematically. Numbers 1 and 2 refer to intermediates whose structure is shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 8 Second part of the DFT calculated reaction pathway for the guanylation of DIC by p–toluidine. TS2a involving hydrogen transfer between the N atoms of the two p-toluidine moieties in intermediate 2 of Fig. 6 has an Ea of 112.2 kJ/mol, while hydrogen transfer from toluidine to the N atom of carbodiimide has an Ea for TS2b of 100.4 kJ/mol. Subsequent Ea for the second hydrogen transfer from toluidine to the N atom of toluidine moiety (TS3a) has an Ea of 60.2 kJ/mol, or (TS3b) 116.0 kJ/mol depending on the first hydrogen transfer and 21.8 kJ/mol if the two consecutive hydrogen transfers from toluidine occur each of the N atoms of the carbodiimide (TS3c). Graphical abstract A series of Ti3C2 samples has been prepared from Ti3AlC2 by NH4F-HCl etching, followed by subsequent post-treatments, such as DMSO expansion, ultrasound exfoliation, thermal annealing at 500 °C, surface modification by ammonium persulfate, tetrabutylammonium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid. These Ti3C2 samples have been tested as heterogeneous catalysts for guanylation of symmetrical carbodiimides by aromatic and secondary aliphatic amines, observing the formation of the corresponding guanidines, accompanied by dialkylureas. The initial reaction rates between N,N’-diisopropylcarbodiimide and p-toluidine correlate linearly with the density of weak strength acid sites of the Ti3C2 sample measured by NH3 thermo-programed desorption. This has led us to propose these weak acid sites as active centers of the reaction. Based on the population of weak acid sites, the estimated turnover numbers and frequencies were calculated to be 101 and 114 h−1 for the most active Ti3C2 sample. These values rank Ti3C2 among the most active noble metal-free solid guanylation catalysts reported so far. Upon reuse, the Ti3C2 sample undergoes gradual deactivation, characterization of the four-times used Ti3C2 sample indicates that the crystallinity is preserved. Catalyst deactivation derives from deposition of the reaction products on the surface and/or from the increase of the oxygenated surface functional groups upon reuse. Deactivation can be partially reversed by thermal product desorption. DFT calculations indicate that the rate determining step in the reaction mechanism is the cycloaddition between the carbodiimide and the deprotonated toluidine anchored to the Ti3C2 surface. The present results illustrate the potential that MXenes have as solid catalysts for organic reactions, particularly Ti MXenes to promote reactions requiring amine activation, such as the present guanylation reaction. Keywords Heterogeneous Catalysis MXenes as catalysts Ti3C2 as catalyst Guanylation of aromatic amines Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Guanidines are widespread compounds in medicinal chemistry, since this structure appears in aminoacids and nucleobases [1]. Several guanidine-containing drugs such as Rosuvastatin, Imatinib, Cimetidine, and Zanamivir are among the best-selling pharmaceuticals, used in a wide range of treatments, including cholesterol control, oncology, gastroprotection, and antihypertensive treatment [2]. Some guanidine polymers are also used as anti-fouling agents in paints for marine protection [3,4]. Among the various possible synthetic approaches, addition of amines to carbodiimides is one of the most appealing routes since it has a complete atom efficiency without the generation of by-products [2]. Symmetric carbodiimides are easily accessible by decarboxylative dimerization of isocyanates [5]. However, although primary aliphatic amines can undergo guanylation by reacting with carbodiimides at high temperatures in the absence of catalysts, [6] more encumbered secondary amines or less nucleophilic aromatic amines do require the presence of catalysts to form guanidines [7]. Most of the reported catalysts for guanylation of aromatic amines are molecular complexes of early transition metals, [8–13] particularly organometallic titanium complexes [14,15]. The use of heterogeneous catalysts for guanylation of aromatic amines is almost unexplored with only a few examples related to supported Lewis acids, such as supported ZnO, Cu2O or Cu nanoparticles [16–19]. Compared to soluble molecular complexes, solid catalysts could offer the advantage of an easy separation from the reaction mixture, the possibility to reuse the material for consecutive runs and the design of continuous flow reactions. For this reason, it is of interest to implement organic syntheses using solid catalysts [20]. Herein, the catalytic activity of Ti3C2 MXenes as heterogeneous catalysts for guanylation of aromatic amines with carbodiimides is presented. The most active sample, multilayered Ti3C2 clay, reaches high turnover frequencies (TOFs) in the order of 102 h−1, higher or comparable to the best solid catalysts so far reported. MXenes are novel 2D nanomaterials constituted by alternating layers of an early transition metal and a carbide or nitride layer [21]. The upper and bottom external surface of MXenes always correspond to metallic sheets that are covered by surface functional groups whose nature depends on the preparation procedure [22]. In the present study and considering that Ti molecular complexes are among the most active homogeneous guanylation catalysts, [2] it will be shown that the multilayered accordion-form of Ti3C2 (Ti3C2–ML, ML corresponding to multi-layer) readily obtained by fluoride etching of Ti3AlC2 MAX precursor exhibits as catalyst a wide substrate scope for guanylation of anilines and secondary aliphatic amines with high TOF values. DFT calculations indicate that the catalytic activity derives from surface defects that allow the interaction of under-coordinated Ti atoms with the aromatic amine. 2 Results and discussion The samples used as catalysts were prepared according to the procedure reported in the literature consisting in the etching of commercially available Ti3AlC2 with a mixture of NH4F and HCl as etching agents [23,24]. After removal of Al, several forms of Ti3C2 samples were screened as catalysts, including the multilayered accordion-like Ti3C2 clay (Ti3C2-ML), DMSO-expanded Ti3C2 clay (Ti3C2-DMSO) and the exfoliated few layers Ti3C2 form (Ti3C2-FL). In the preparation of the exfoliated few layers Ti3C2, DMSO was used as expanding agent to increase the interlayer distance in the initial accordion-like MXene clay directly obtained in the Al etching, facilitating subsequent exfoliation of the individual sheets by ultrasounds [25]. Scheme 1 illustrates the Ti3C2 sample preparation. It is known that the nature and distribution of the termination groups present on the surface of the MXene depends on the synthetic route used to prepare the material. When using NH4F and HCl as Al etchants, F and Cl atoms are installed on the surface of Ti3C2, along with OH and −O − groups coming from the aqueous medium [26,27]. The etching process also introduces defects on the Ti3C2 structure, including under coordinated Ti atoms and Ti vacancies [28]. After Al etching, the surface functional groups can be altered, at least in part, by post-synthetic treatment. It was one of the hypotheses of the present study that the nature of these surface terminations and their vacancies should play a key role in the catalysis, making possible the coordination of the reagents with Ti atoms acting as Lewis sites. For this reason, as indicated in Scheme 1, in addition to the Ti3C2-ML clay, DMSO-expanded Ti3C2-DMSO and exfoliated Ti3C2-FL sheets, other Ti3C2 samples were prepared by post-synthetic treatment of the DMSO-expanded sample. Thus, Ti3C2-DMSO acted as a precursor of three additional Ti3C2 samples in which Ti3C2-DMSO was reacted either with hydrochloric acid (HCl) to introduce further Ti vacancies and −Cl atoms, or with ammonium persulfate (APS) to increase the proportion of −O- groups [29] or tetrabutyl ammonium hydroxide (TBAOH) that is a reagent known to install –OH terminations [30,31]. As reported, surface characterization by XPS analysis provides a strong evidence of the alteration of the nature and distribution of the surface groups. Fig. S1 in supporting information provides EDX analysis of the Ti3C2 samples under study. Additionally, the presence of DMSO in Ti3C2-DMSO was confirmed by solid-state 13C NMR spectroscopy, which showed a signal at 46.09 ppm corresponding to the methyl (CH3) carbon atoms of DMSO (Fig. S2) [32]. For the sake of comparison of the activity of Ti3C2 with that of other MXenes, Nb2C and V2C were also prepared by analogous fluoride salts and HCl etching of their corresponding Nb2AlC and V2AlC precursors following reported procedures [33–35]. Supporting information provides a detailed description of the preparation of all MXene samples used in the present study as heterogeneous catalysts and appropriate characterization data. The list of samples and their main analytical parameters are given in Table 1 . The MXene samples were characterized by XRD, TEM, AFM and XPS. Thus, the success of Al etching was confirmed by XRD in which the diffraction patterns of the MAX phase precursor changed during the etching process giving the expected peaks at 18.5°, 27° and 36° corresponding to the (004), (006) and (008) planes reported for the accordion-like form of the corresponding MXenes [36,37]. Fig. 1 (a) compares the XRD patterns of the Ti3AlC2 precursor, the resulting Ti3C2-ML and expanded Ti3C2-DMSO to illustrate the remarkable changes occurring during the Al etching and the effect of DMSO intercalation. Based on the 2θ value of the (002 peak (Fig. 1 a and Table S1), the interlayer distance in the stacking was estimated as 1.11 and 1.12 nm for the Ti3C2-ML and Ti3C2-DMSO samples, respectively. These interlayer distance values are in the range of those values reported in the literature for these Ti3C2 MXene forms. It should be noted, however, that the actual interlayer distance in a Ti3C2 sample is known to depend also on the exact exfoliation conditions, particularly the time of the etching treatment [38]. Also, the interlayer distances measured for Ti3C2-APS and Ti3C2-HCl of 1.08 and 1.13 nm coincide with the reported value for these samples [36]. Interestingly, in the case of Ti3C2-TBAOH, a significantly larger interlayer distance of 1.49 nm based on XRD (Fig. S3) was determined probably indicating the intercalation of large quaternary ammonium ions in the material, therefore resulting in an expansion between neighbor sheets [39]. In this regard, the presence of N atoms on the composition of some of the Ti3C2 samples prepared in this study (see Table 1) should derive from the use in their preparation of NH4F for Ti3C2–DMSO, and both NH4F and NH4SO5H for Ti3C2–APS or NH4F and TBA+ for Ti3C2–TBAOH. In the case of DMSO-expanded and exfoliated Ti3C2 samples, the average thickness of the 2D nanosheets was determined by AFM measurements with subnanometric vertical resolution by determining the height of a statistically relevant number of particles, resulting for Ti3C2-DMSO an average sheet thickness of 4.1 ± 1.2 nm that corresponds approximately to the stacking of four MXene layers as average. In contrast, Fig. 1 b shows the thickness of multi-layer Ti3C2-ML showing a broad thickness distribution for this sample [40]. These images also showed that the lateral particle size of the Ti3C2 samples is of a few hundreds of nanometers, much smaller that other micrometric MXene flakes reported in the literature. However, it has to be noted that for the purpose of using these samples in catalysis, smaller lateral flakes are more appropriate since catalytic activity frequently increases as the particle size decreases. Similar average thickness was also determined for Ti3C2-HCl after exfoliation. However, in the case of the other two samples derived from Ti3C2-DMSO by post-synthetic treatment, namely Ti3C2-APS and Ti3C2-TBAOH, the surface modification process apparently produced agglomeration of the MXene particles, resulting in much thicker aggregates ranging from 22 to even 150 nm (Fig. S4). It could be that this post-synthetic treatment diminishes the surface charge of the particles or increases their interaction, therefore, favoring stacking or agglomeration of the primary individual particles into much larger aggregates. Crystallinity of the present MXene samples and average lateral size dimensions were determined by transmission electron microscopy. Fig. 1 (c) shows representative TEM images taken for Ti3C2-DMSO showing the lattice fringes with a spacing of 0.261 nm corresponding to the (0 1 ¯ 10) plane in XRD [41]. In addition, selected area electron diffraction also shows the characteristic hexagonal pattern indicating the single crystalline domain of the particle. By recording selected area electron diffraction (SAED) in different parts of the image field at lower resolution, the high crystallinity of the Ti3C2-ML and Ti3C2-DMSO sample was confirmed. Similar images were also taken for the other samples under study indicating that post-synthetic treatment to alter the nature of the surface groups does not affect the crystal structure of the MXene (Fig. S5). SAED allowed to estimate the interplanar distance for some of the crystallographic planes of Ti3C2 MXenes observed by TEM. Table S1 provides these values, showing good agreement between the interplanar distance measured by SAED with some of the XRD peaks. Fig. 2 shows the high-resolution XP spectra of C 1s, O 1s, and Ti 2p core levels of Ti3C2-DMSO. Fitting of the experimental C 1s spectrum indicates four components corresponding to C bonded to Ti (281.2 eV), graphitic carbon and C atoms of DMSO (284.5 eV), C bonded to O (286.5 eV) and COOH carboxylate (288.3 eV). The XPS Ti 2p core level was adequately deconvoluted into several peaks corresponding to Ti bonded to C (454.3 eV), to O (455.6 eV), and to F (458.4 eV). The high resolution O 1s peak displays two components assigned to Ti-O (529.8 eV) and residual H2O/CO3 = (532.2 eV). The F 1s spectrum was fit in two components corresponding to –F terminations (Ti-F, 684 eV and C-F, 685.3 eV). All the previous XPS data are in good agreement with the literature [42]. XPS analysis also indicates the presence of Cl on the sample. The Cl 2p core level has two peaks at 198.2 and 200.0 eV attributable to Ti-Cl and C-Cl. Finally, the presence of N in low proportion was also detectable by XPS that shows a distribution of N atoms between Ti-N and N–H components appearing at 399.4 and 401.0 eV, respectively. The most likely origin of Cl and N are HCl and NH4F reagents using for Al etching. XP spectra of Ti3C2-ML, Ti3C2-HCl, Ti3C2-APS and Ti3C2-TBAOH are presented in Fig. S6 of the supplementary material and were also in agreement with the reported data [42]. 2.1 Catalytic activity The reaction of p-toluidine with N,N'-diisopropylcarbodiimide was selected as benchmark reaction performing the addition under conditions in which variations in activity due to higher or lower catalytic performance can occur. Preliminary blank controls in the absence of catalyst showed that p-toluidine does not react with N, N'-diisopropylcarbodiimide in toluene at reflux temperature in 24 h. In contrast, the presence of MXene in the medium promotes the formation of the corresponding 1,3-diisopropyl-2-(p-tolyl)guanidine, accompanied by N, N'-diisopropylurea, as indicated in eq. (1) . While guanidine corresponds to the reaction of carbodiimide with p-toluidine, N,N'-diisopropylurea derives from the addition of water present on the MXene catalysts, in the solvent or in the medium [37]. The initial reaction rate of guanidine formation and final p-toluidine conversion at 24 h depended on the composition and preparation procedure of the MXene used as catalyst. Fig. S7 in the supporting information displays the temporal profiles of p-toluidine conversion (Fig. S7(a)) and guanylation of N,N'-diisopropylcarbodiimide to 1,3-diisopropyl-2-(p-tolyl)guanidine (Fig. S7(b)) using Ti3C2-ML, Ti3C2-DMSO, V2C and Nb2C as catalysts at 100 °C. Transition metal complexes such as titanium or vanadium imido complexes have been previously reported to catalyze the guanylation of primary aromatic amines with inactivated carbodiimides, with Ti complexes being the best performing ones [2]. When comparing the activity of the different MXene catalysts, it was found that Ti3C2 displays the best activity for the guanylation reaction, followed by Nb2C and V2C, thus agreeing with the activity reported for their homogeneous counterparts [12,13,15]. Note that the three MXenes were prepared following analogous etching procedures and, therefore, it can be assumed that they must have similar surface functional groups. (1) Having found Ti3C2-DMSO as a suitable guanylation catalyst, further studies were aimed at improving its catalytic activity and to learn more about the influence of surface functional groups. In this regard, the effect of interlayer expansion using DMSO followed by ultrasound exfoliation in comparison with the multilayered Ti3C2-ML accordion-form directly resulting from the NH4F/HCl etching was studied. The results plotted in Fig. S7(b) show that the exfoliation procedure is detrimental for the catalytic activity with the most active Ti3C2 form being the sample resulting directly from Al etching (Ti3C2-ML). Since exfoliation should be beneficial in terms of larger specific surface area and better site exposure, the lower catalytic activity of Ti3C2-DMSO respect to pristine Ti3C2-ML can be attributed to the negative effect caused by the presence of adsorbed DMSO that remains on the Ti3C2-DMSO sample used as catalyst, as detected by solid-state 13C NMR spectroscopy in the Ti3C2-DMSO sample before the reaction (Fig. S2). DMSO could be blocking some active sites and it should also increase hydrophilicity favoring N,N'-diisopropylurea formation. To assess the effect of MXene surface termination on the catalytic activity, the catalytic activity of Ti3C2-DMSO with Ti3C2-HCl, Ti3C2-APS and Ti3C2-TBAOH was compared. Note that, as indicated in Scheme 1, Ti3C2-HCl, Ti3C2-APS and Ti3C2-TBAOH derive directly from Ti3C2-DMSO by further post-synthetic treatment. Ti3C2-HCl was obtained by treating Ti3C2-DMSO by HCl to generate further Ti atom vacancies and introducing Ti-Cl terminations at the same time. Fig. 4 (a) and S8 show the temporal profiles of 1,3-diisopropyl-2-(p-tolyl)guanidine yield and p-toluidine conversion respectively, using post-synthetically modified Ti3C2. From this data, it can be concluded that although all the Ti3C2 samples exhibit catalytic activity, post-synthetic treatments exert a negative influence in the Ti3C2 performance, the most active sample being Ti3C2-DMSO. These results indicate that surface functionality plays an important role on the catalytic activity and that oxygenated surface groups introduced by APS or TBAOH treatments are not the active sites [43]. In the case of the Ti3C2-HCl sample, generation of additional Ti atom vacancies appears to be compensated by formation of Ti-Cl terminations, resulting the balance in a similar catalytic activity for Ti3C2-HCl and Ti3C2-DMSO. The catalytic performance of Ti3C2-based materials is closely linked to their surface chemistry and acid site distribution as summarized in Table S3. Analysis of the catalyst series reveals that weak acidity correlates linearly with guanidine formation, suggesting that acidity plays a pivotal role in the catalysis. This is evident for Ti3C2-ML, which possesses the highest population of weak acid sites (0.099 mmol/g) and achieves the highest guanidine yield (14.7 %) at 100 °C. In contrast, catalysts dominated by strong acidity, such as Ti3C2-TBAOH (2.238 mmol/g of strong acid sites, 0 mmol/g weak acidity), exhibit markedly lower guanidine yields (5.2 %), suggesting that excessive strong acid sites may lead to undesirable side reactions, such as urea formation. Ti3C2-DMSO, with a distribution of acid sites from strong, moderate and weak strength, exhibits a preferent selectivity for 1,3-diisopropylurea (21.2 % yield) formation. This indicates that moderate and strong acidity enhances urea formation, whereas guanidine synthesis benefits from a higher population of weak acidity and diminished strong acid density. Surface oxygen content, primarily from –O and –OH functionalities, correlates with total acidity but does not independently predict catalytic performance. Thus, Ti3C2-APS, with the highest oxygen content (32.4 %), shows poor catalytic activity. Furthermore, the presence of surface chlorine (e.g., in Ti3C2-ML and Ti3C2-HCl) may contribute to slightly enhanced guanidine yields, potentially through stabilization of reactive intermediates. These findings underscore the critical influence of tailored surface functionalization and acid site strength tuning on the catalytic selectivity in guanidine synthesis. Table S3 summarizes these findings. To better rank the relative activity of Ti3C2-DMSO and Ti3C2-ML, the activity as guanylation catalysts of both samples was compared at different temperatures in the range from 90 °C to 130 °C. Fig. 3 presents a comparison of the temporal profiles of the 1,3-diisopropyl-2-(p-tolyl)guanidine yield using Ti3C2-ML and Ti3C2-DMSO as catalysts. As it can be seen in Fig. 3, although the overall reaction yields at 90 °C and 100 °C for both samples are comparable (Fig. 3), Ti3C2-ML exhibits superior activity toward guanidine formation. This trend is accompanied by a significantly lower 1,3-diisopropylurea yield (10.2 % for Ti3C2-ML vs. 21.2 % for Ti3C2-DMSO) (Fig. S9). At 130 °C, the guanidine yield with Ti3C2-ML further increases to 29.6 %, more than double that of Ti3C2-DMSO (14.6 %), underscoring the enhanced catalytic efficiency and selectivity of the ML catalyst. The reduced guanidine formation in Ti3C2-DMSO is attributed to its pronounced hygroscopic nature, [44] derived from the presence of DMSO. This hydrophilicity will favor water uptake, promoting the hydrolysis of carbodiimide intermediates to urea. Additionally, temperature-programmed NH3 desorption (NH3-TPD) analysis indicates a higher density of strong acid sites in Ti3C2-DMSO (Table S2), which can further catalyze the hydrolysis of carbodiimides, [45,46] thus favoring 1,3-diisopropylurea formation. These combined effects of greater moisture retention and increased acidity account for the diminished guanidine selectivity in Ti3C2-DMSO and highlight the advantageous properties of Ti3C2-ML as a more selective catalyst in guanidine synthesis. Having found that the Ti3C2-ML clay resulting directly from Al-etching of Ti3AlC2 was the most active sample and that 130 °C is a convenient temperature affording high guanidine yield while still having room for improvement, exfoliation treatment of Ti3C2-ML avoiding the use of any expansion agent by sonication in pure H2O was performed, observing also in this case a decrease in the catalytic activity (Fig. 4 (b)). Ultrasound treatment is able to break the 2D nanosheets of the Ti3C2-ML clay resulting in a significant decrease in the lateral size of the particles [47]. However, this treatment also introduces oxygenated surface groups, healing surface termination vacancies by further exposure to H2O [48]. The balance of these opposite effects, i.e., larger surface area by exfoliation and unwanted alteration of surface functional groups, leads in the present case to a decrease in catalytic activity of the Ti3C2-ML sample after sonication. Additionally, Ti3C2-ML after sonication was submitted to a further thermal treatment at 500 °C under Ar atmosphere. From the information provided by thermogravimetry and analysis of the molecules evolved in the process, [49] it was determined that pristine Ti3C2-ML directly obtained in the Al etching from the Ti3AlC2 phase evolves some surface functional groups, particularly some H2O formed by condensation of two neighbor Ti-OH groups and formation of Ti-O-Ti oxo bridges. Accordingly, it was of interest to determine the influence of this treatment on the catalytic activity of the resulting Ti3C2-FL-500. The results presented in Fig. 4 (b) and S10 show a notable decrease in the catalytic activity of Ti3C2-FL-500 for 1,3-diisopropyl-2-(p-tolyl)guanidine formation and p-toluidine conversion respectively. It is proposed that the observed decrease in catalytic activity is a consequence of the healing of defects and formation of surface oxo bridges in the heating treatment. The heterogeneous nature of the catalytic activity was determined by carrying out a hot filtration test. In this test, two twin reactions start under the general conditions, but in one of them the Ti3C2-ML catalyst is filtered at 1 h at the reaction temperature once the conversion has reached 5 %. The resulting clear solution is allowed to react further in the absence of solid catalyst. Fig. S11 shows the results of the hot filtration test. It was observed that after filtration of the Ti3C2-ML catalyst the reaction stops, while in the twin reaction p-toluidine conversion progresses up to 29 %. In addition, ICP analysis of the clear solution at the end of the reaction showed that the Ti content was about 0.5 % of the initial Ti content present in the Ti3C2-ML catalyst. These data support that the reaction requires the presence of Ti3C2-ML solid to occur and that Ti3C2-ML is not leaching active species to the liquid phase. 2.2 Nature of the active sites At this point and after having measured the catalytic activity of a series of Ti3C2 samples for p-toluidine guanylation, it was desirable to find a technique to correlate their activity with some properties of the material. Particularly, catalytic activity of solids is frequently related to the acid-base properties of the surface. Acidity and basicity of solids can be routinely quantified by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) measurements of ammonia and CO2, respectively. In the present case, the use of NH3 as probe molecule is particularly relevant considering the structural similarity between the functional groups of amines and NH3. In other words, it is reasonable to propose that the sites on Ti3C2 that are able to interact with p-toluidine– should also adsorb NH3· NH3-TPD measurements for the Ti3C2 samples is provided in Fig. S12. As seen in the NH3​ desorption profiles, three relative NH3 desorption maxima are observed at approximately 175 °C, 400 °C, and 570 °C, corresponding to sites with weak, medium, and strong basicity strength, respectively [50,51]. The corresponding amount of desorbed NH3 at each temperature is indicated in Table S2. To know if any of these sites, either weak, medium or strong, are the active sites, the initial guanidine formation rate was plotted against the amount of these sites as determined by NH3-TPD analyses. The results are presented in Fig. S13. As shown there, while the strong acid sites do not correlate with the initial reaction rate for Ti3C2-ML samples, the plot of the initial guanylation rate vs. the population of weak acid sites exhibits a reasonable linear relationship for samples derived from Ti3C2-ML and Ti3C2-DMSO under different reaction conditions. Thus, the increase in the population of weak acid sites leads to a proportional growth of guanylation rate. Based on this, it is proposed that the catalytic activity of the MXene samples for guanylation of carbodiimide by p-toluidine derives from Lewis acid sites of weak strength. This is in agreement with the previous knowledge in the catalysis of this reaction, in which control of the Lewis acid strength is necessary to achieve an optimal guanylation reaction performance [2]. For sites of stronger acidity, product desorption can be disfavored, particularly considering that guanidines can behave as superbases [52]. In fact it was noticed in some time-yield plots that the reaction rate decreases considerably once a certain product yield is achieved (see Figs. 3 and 4). This fact can be rationalized assuming that the reaction product acts as a poison of the active sites, competing with toluidine for the active site and blocking Lewis acid sites. To provide some support to the poisoning effect of guanidine for the MXene active sites, while reinforcing the proposal of Lewis acid sites, even with weak strength as active sites, three catalytic tests using Ti3C2-ML were carried out by adding purposely at initial time 1,3–diisopropyl-2-(p-tolyl)guanidine at two different concentrations in the range of those formed at around 8 and 21 h of reaction. The results presented in Fig. S14 show a linear decrease in the initial guanylation reaction rate as a function of the guanidine concentration, thereby confirming the poisoning effect of the reaction product. Regarding the poisoning effect of guanidine, it has to be commented that this product has much lower toluene solubility than the starting materials. This lower solubility, due to the presence of polar N–H groups that can form strong hydrogen bonds, is responsible for the observation of some product precipitation upon cooling the reaction mixture when the concentration of the products is high and can also contribute to surface poisoning. Aliphatic and aromatic amines have obviously larger molecular size than NH3 used as probe molecule in NH3-TPD. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that some of the Lewis acid sites probed by NH3 are sterically too encumbered to interact with amines and cannot perform as active sites in the guanylation reaction. However, taking the population of weak acid sites quantified by NH3-TPD as the number of active sites, a lower estimate for the turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF) of Ti3C2-ML can be determined. It is likely that the number of weak strength sites quantified by NH3 overestimates the number of sites that promote guanylation, but the TON and TOF values can serve as initial rough data to rank Ti3C2-ML activity with respect to reported homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. These values are given in Table 2 . Although comparison of the catalytic activity based on literature data is always problematic due to the disparity in the reaction conditions in which the values are measured, the data shown in Table 2 clearly points to a high intrinsic Ti3C2-ML catalytic activity frequently two or more orders of magnitude higher than conventional solid catalysts. Worth noting is that in comparison to other reported guanylation catalysts Ti3C2-ML does not contain precious or critical metals in its composition. The influence on the reaction rate of the reaction temperature in the range from 90 °C to 130 °C is given in Fig. 3 . From these data, the Arrhenius plot allows to calculate the activation energy using Ti3C2-ML as catalysts. The value of 71.3 ± 11.7 kJ/mol mol−1 (Fig. S15) indicates a moderate activation barrier for the transition state, which is consistent with the good performance of Ti3C2-ML compared to other reported catalysts. 2.3 Reaction scope The general catalytic activity of Ti3C2-ML to promote guanylation of amines was confirmed by screening several para- and ortho-substituted aromatic amines as well as secondary aliphatic amines for different symmetrical carbodiimides. Table 3 shows the products obtained and the corresponding conversion and product yields, while Figs. S16 to S19 shows the time-yield plots of these reactions. All the reaction products were isolated by flash chromatography with yields close to the values determined by GC analyses. The corresponding 1H NMR spectra in CD2Cl2 solution are provided Figs. S33-S49 in supporting information. As it can be seen in Table 3, Ti3C2-ML promotes the formation of a variety of guanidines. In the case of aromatic amines, electron donor substituents increase substrate conversion and guanidine yield (Table 3, entries 1 and 3), while the opposite occurs for electron withdrawing substituents (Table 3, entries 4 and 5). This trend is in agreement with the positive effect of the electronic density on the N lone electron pair on aniline reactivity. In the case of aminostyrene, occurrence of C=C polymerization in a significant extent competing with guanylation was observed, resulting in high conversion of the aromatic amine, but low p-styryl guanidine yield (Table 3, entry 7). Steric encumbrance around the –NH2 group decreases considerably the conversion and product yield as seen in the case of o-toluidine (Table 3, entry 6). As expected in view of their high reactivity and large nucleophilicity, secondary amines such as pyrrolidine, morpholine and piperidine, were far more reactive than aromatic amines and excellent yields were achieved for the corresponding guanidines at shorter times. To demonstrate the role of the catalyst in the guanylation of pyrrolidine with N,N'-diisopropylcarbodiimide at 130 °C, a blank experiment without the catalyst was performed, yielding 67 % after 6 h. In contrast, the presence of Ti3C2-ML resulted in a 99 % yield under the same conditions and time. Thus, the catalytic activity of Ti3C2-ML is much lower for encumbered aromatic amines, aromatic amines having electron withdrawing substituents or reactive functional groups. This trend is the one expected considering the general reactivity of aromatic amines. Besides N,N-diisopropylcarbodiimide, larger molecular weight N,N'-dicyclohexylcarbodiimide was also used as substrate, observing the formation of the corresponding guanidines with similar conversions and yields as for the isopropyl analog. To assess the reusability of Ti3C2-ML, the reaction was scaled up to use a larger Ti3C2-ML amount that could allow easier recovery of the catalyst and reuse the same sample in successive runs under the same conditions. In this way four consecutive uses of the same Ti3C2-ML sample were carried out. Each run was performed for 24 h. As it can be seen in Fig. S20, a gradual decrease in the catalytic activity was observed under these conditions going from 30 % guanidine yield at final time for the fresh sample to 5 % in the fourth use. Between catalytic cycles, the used catalyst was washed twice with toluene, once with dichloromethane, and then dried at ambient temperature prior to reuse. Under these conditions, the guanidine yield dropped by approximately half in the second run and subsequently exhibited a slight, gradual deactivation over further reuses. Considering the solubility of both reaction products, guanidine and urea, it is proposed that the Ti3C2-ML sample becomes poisoned by these products as the reaction progresses, decreasing the reaction rate. Besides poisoning, alteration of the surface terminal groups and, particularly, healing of surface group vacancies that are presumed to behave as active sites would also contribute to this deactivation. As already commented when discussing the catalytic activity of post-synthetically modified Ti3C2-APS and Ti3C2-TBAOH, the guanylation catalytic activity largely depends on the nature of these surface terminations and the presence of defects. Then, upon reuse, the original surface of the pristine Ti3C2-ML sample would be altered by product deposition and exposure to moisture and ambient humidity, resulting in an increase of oxygenated surface termination. This proposal on Ti3C2-ML deactivation upon reuse is reasonable considering the strong adsorption of nitrogenated products and reagents and the tendency of Ti3C2 to undergo oxidation [16,53]. To provide some support to this proposal of poisoning by product deposition and surface modification, XPS analysis of the four times used Ti3C2-ML sample was performed. The corresponding XPS data as well as the best deconvolution to the individual components are presented in Fig. S21. Although there are many similarities between the four times used sample and the pristine Ti3C2-ML material, some specific changes were noted. First the percentage of C, O and N atoms on the surface undergoes a significant increase with respect to the fresh sample. In addition, the C 1s showed a decrease in the proportion of the C-Ti component at 281.3 eV, that is also accompanied by an increase in the proportion of the TiO2–xF2x/TiO2 components in the deconvolution of the Ti 2p core level. These variations indicate an enrichment of C, N and O on the catalyst surface compatible with the deposition of some reaction products adsorbed on the surface and remaining in the sample after the washings and with the higher population of −O- groups with respect to −F and −Cl surface atoms. It is proposed that these changes are responsible for the observed catalyst deactivation. Further quantification of the organic material deposited on Ti3C2-ML was made by thermogravimetric analysis under air of the four times used Ti3C2-ML sample. A 40 % weight loss was measured in the temperature range from ambient temperature to 400 °C for the four times used Ti3C2-ML sample that should correspond to the adsorbed organic matter. Fig. S22 provides the thermogravimetric profile of the four times used Ti3C2-ML in comparison to the pristine material. To confirm that the 2D crystal structure of MXene is maintained under the reaction conditions, the Ti3C2-ML sample used four times was further characterized by TEM and XRD. The results are presented in Figs. S23 and S24, respectively. Although some deterioration of the crystallinity cannot be excluded, both characterization techniques confirm that the four times used Ti3C2-ML sample is still a crystalline material. Based on the thermogravimetric profile of the Ti3C2-ML after four uses, the solid was calcined in air at 200 °C for 30 min to remove the adsorbed organic residues. The diffractograms presented in Fig. S24 confirm that the material retains its crystal structure and that Ti3C2-ML does not transform into TiO2 at this temperature even in the presence of air. Fig. S25 displays the FTIR spectra of Ti3C2-ML, Ti3C2-ML-R and Ti3C2-ML-Cal, showing that calcination at 200 °C removes a major part of the organic matter that was adsorbed on the reused material. In addition, XPS of Ti3C2-ML-Calc (Fig. S26) shows that thermal regeneration induces marked, element-specific modifications in Ti3C2 consisting in a drop of the Ti-C carbide signal from 14.9 % to 12.5 % in C 1s, and a concomitant loss of ≤ 8 % Ti-C in the Ti 2p at 454.6 eV, confirming conversion of up to one-tenth of the outermost carbide layer to TiOx. Correspondingly, Ti-F terminations decrease by 4 %, while Ti-Cl falls by 3 %. N 1s peak remains largely intact. Overall, the XPS analysis shows significant surface oxidation and partial loss of halide terminations. The calcined material was then tested for the guanylation of p-toluidine, yielding 22 % after 24 h compared to the 17 % yield in the second use, indicating a significant regeneration of the catalytic activity after four uses. These findings further validate that the strong adsorption of organic matter is a major contributing factor for catalyst deactivation. To gain deeper insight into the adsorption of both the aromatic amine and the resulting guanidine formed during the guanylation of aromatic amines with aliphatic carbodiimides, an in-situ FTIR spectroscopy study of the guanylation reaction occurring on the surface of Ti3C2-ML was conducted. Detailed experimental procedures for these in situ adsorption measurements are provided in the supporting information. A slight bathochromic shift of about 4 cm−1 is observed when aniline adsorbs onto the surface of Ti3C2-ML. This shift may be attributed to the interaction between aniline NH2 groups and the MXene surface groups. For example, the stretching bands of aniline, originally observed at 3422, 3351, and 3213 cm–1, shift to 3419, 3347, and 3209 cm–1, respectively, as shown in Fig. S27 (a–d). Additionally, the NH2 bending vibration shifts from 1620 to 1616 cm–1, further confirming the interaction between aniline and the MXene. Moreover, the broadening of the stretching band around 3422 cm–1 provides further evidence of hydrogen bonding between aniline and the catalyst [54]. Subsequently diiisopropylcarbodiimide was added to the sample of adsorbed aniline and Ti3C2-ML and heated at 130 °C, while monitoring the evolution of the system over the time by FTIR spectroscopy. IR spectra reveal that during the reaction, new features emerge in the 2360–2340 cm–1 region of the IR spectrum recorded at 30 min, a time sufficiently long to observe the evolution of intermediates. The IR spectral changes are presented in Fig. S28 (a-c). These spectral features in the region corresponding to accumulated N=C=N bonds and aromatic overtones that do not correspond to aniline, carbodiimide or guanidine supports the appearance of a reaction intermediate when both reagents are adsorbed onto the Ti3C2 surface, most probably in which the accumulated N=C=N is still present. 2.4 DFT calculations Further understanding on the reaction mechanism and the nature of the active sites can be obtained by theoretical modelling and calculations. Theoretical calculations on Ti3C2 usually employs Ti2C as model to save computational cost, while providing reasonable similarity in the local environments at the MXene surface [55]. In the present case a model of 35 atoms based on Ti2CTx, with T corresponding to the surface terminal groups in the experimental proportion determined by XPS for Ti3C2-ML was used for the calculations. Employing this Ti2CTx model, the initial mechanistic proposal was based on the accepted guanylation mechanism using molecular Ti complexes as catalysts as indicated in Scheme 2 [2,14]. In this mechanism, the first step is the adsorption of activation of p-toluidine on the MXene surface via double deprotonation and nitrogen binding to the Ti atoms. Once p-toluidine deprotonation with the spill over of two protons on MXene surface has occurred, the following steps will lead to the reaction product, regenerating the catalyst for the subsequent reaction cycles. This mechanism based on Scheme 2 was computed on the 35-atom model cluster of the MXene surface, shown in Fig. 5 , which includes O2–, (OH)- and F- functionalities, that are present in the experimental characterization. According to Scheme 2, the key step of the mechanism corresponds to the cycloaddition of the N,N'-diisopropylcarbodiimide (DIC), yielding intermediate 1 (shown on Fig. 6 ). After this step, the following intermediate corresponds to the adsorption of another toluidine molecule on the MXene surface (intermediate 2). From intermediate 2, the reaction proceeds from transferring two protons from adsorbed p-toluidine to adsorbed guanidine, there being three possibilities depending on which N atom of the adsorbed guanidine is receiving the first and which the second proton. All these three possibilities were computed and the geometry and energy of the corresponding intermediates, differing in the position of the protons were determined. Figs. S29-S32 in the supporting information shows the structures of these intermediates. As these Figs. S29-S32 show, the last product formed regenerates the MXene catalyst structure shown on Fig. 5 , forming the corresponding expected products. 2.4.1 Energetic profile of the reaction coordinate As shown in Scheme 2, the first part of the catalytic cycle leading to the cycloadduct is common regardless the subsequent order of proton transfer from p-toluidine to the adsorbed carbodiimide. The energy of the transition states (TS) in these elementary pathways is presented in Fig. 7 . The cycloaddition reaction between the MXene catalyst and DIC forming intermediate 1 is endothermic by 57.7 kJ/mol, probably because during reaction the adsorbed deprotonated p-toluidine must lose coordination, since it must go from coordinating to three Ti atoms on the surface to only two. This “vacancy” is then filled with another p-toluidine, in an exothermic step, leading from intermediate 1 to intermediate 2. As indicated in Scheme 2, from intermediate 2 there are three possible proton transfer pathways with three possible intermediates. Fig. 8 shows that the predicted favored pathway implies a first hydrogen transfer from toluidine to the N atom of the carbodiimide, followed by a second hydrogen transfer from p-toluidine to the other N atom of carbodiimide. As indicated in Fig. 8, both hydrogen transfers are exothermic with activation barriers for TS2b and TS3c of 100.4 and 20.8 kJ × mol−1, respectively. Lastly, the second hydrogen transfer is always exothermic, no matter to which N atom was transferred the first hydrogen from toluidine. Overall, the present calculations indicate that p-toluidine addition to carbodiimide on the MXene follows a reaction mechanism analogous to the one accepted to occur for molecular complexes with the main difference that while in the homogeneous catalyst the Ti atom can have up to three coordination positions involved in product formation (see intermediates 2, 3 and 4 in Scheme 2), this is not possible in the case of MXene surface in which Ti atoms can offer only a single coordination position to the reaction mechanism and, as consequence, the mechanism require the involvement of up to three neighbour Ti atoms to promote the addition. 3 Conclusions It has been shown that MXenes can catalyze guanylation of carbodiimides by aromatic and secondary amines forming the corresponding 2-substituted guanidines. The process is accompanied by formation of dialkylurea resulting from addition to the carbodiimide of H2O present in the MXene or/and from the ambient. Ti3C2 performs better than Nb2C or V2C and the preparation procedure and post-treatment of the Ti3C2 sample exerts a notable influence on the catalytic activity, depending on the surface terminal groups. Among the various Ti3C2 samples, the clay resulting directly from NH4F-HCl etching of the Ti3AlC2 was found to be the most active one, expansion by DMSO, exfoliation by ultrasounds, and the installation of oxygenated groups being detrimental for the catalytic activity. A linear relationship between the initial reaction rate and the density of weak strength acid sites, suggest that these Lewis sites related to surface functional groups vacancies and defects are responsible for the catalytic activity. Estimation of the TON and TOF values based on the population of weak strength acid sites give values of 101 and 114 h−1, respectively, that are among the highest values reported for guanylation catalysts. The Ti3C2 sample undergoes gradual deactivation upon reuse due to the deposition of guanidine and urea on the MXene surface and the gradual alteration of the Ti3C2 surface by introduction of oxygenated groups. DFT calculations support a mechanism analogous to that accepted for molecular complexes, but in which the amine becomes deprotonated and attached to three neighbor Ti atoms on the surface and the rate determining step being the cycloaddition of carbodiimide by the deprotonated toluidine. Overall, the present results show the potential of MXenes as heterogenous catalysts for organic reactions. Particularly the present data indicates that Ti MXenes can be general catalysts for those reactions involving amines as reagents in which a fine tuning of the acid strength and the cooperation of more than one transition metal on the surface are required to activate these molecules. 4 Materials and methods All the information regarding materials and methods used in this study is provided in the Supporting Information. coredata.dc:description: A series of Ti3C2 samples has been prepared from Ti3AlC2 by NH4F-HCl etching, followed by subsequent post-treatments, such as DMSO expansion, ultrasound exfoliation, thermal annealing at 500 °C, surface modification by ammonium persulfate, tetrabutylammonium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid. These Ti3C2 samples have been tested as heterogeneous catalysts for guanylation of symmetrical carbodiimides by aromatic and secondary aliphatic amines, observing the formation of the corresponding guanidines, accompanied by dialkylureas. The initial reaction rates between N,N’-diisopropylcarbodiimide and p-toluidine correlate linearly with the density of weak strength acid sites of the Ti3C2 sample measured by NH3 thermo-programed desorption. This has led us to propose these weak acid sites as active centers of the reaction. Based on the population of weak acid sites, the estimated turnover numbers and frequencies were calculated to be 101 and 114 h−1 for the most active Ti3C2 sample. These values rank Ti3C2 among the most active noble metal-free solid guanylation catalysts reported so far. Upon reuse, the Ti3C2 sample undergoes gradual deactivation, characterization of the four-times used Ti3C2 sample indicates that the crystallinity is preserved. Catalyst deactivation derives from deposition of the reaction products on the surface and/or from the increase of the oxygenated surface functional groups upon reuse. Deactivation can be partially reversed by thermal product desorption. DFT calculations indicate that the rate determining step in the reaction mechanism is the cycloaddition between the carbodiimide and the deprotonated toluidine anchored to the Ti3C2 surface. The present results illustrate the potential that MXenes have as solid catalysts for organic reactions, particularly Ti MXenes to promote reactions requiring amine activation, such as the present guanylation reaction.
